Based Jungian anon. I've never thought about this before, but I do have some experience with -STJs, and seeing as I'm an INTJ, perhaps I can help.

First off, an INFJ may have the most difficult time of all writing for an ESTJ in my opinion. For reasons I won't go into here, I believe your type represses the dominant function of the ESTJ, Te, more than any other function. Conversely, the ESTJ does the same. Ni, your and my dominant, is their most repressed function - just like the ESFJ. With that in mind it might be helpful for you to think of a sort of cloud of other types which fluidly relate to the ESTJ and which might be easier for you to comprehend the perspective of.

On the one hand you have the following:
>ESTP - alike in preference for thinking and extroverted judgement, both repress their feelings to the point of not noticing - ESTJs less so, thus more driven by an undercurrent of feeling heavily rooted in a Te-Fi "objective, generally common-sensical" morality
>ISTP - their mirror - both are driven to act quickly and efficiently with no frills. The ISTP tends more towards doing this with a stylish and idiosyncratic eye due to hyper-repressed Fi, while the ESTJ, repressing Ni is striving for insight and manifestation of a longterm vision (the 4-7 link Fi-Ni). As with all types, this will be best viewed through the lens of their 2-5 function link. Si-Ti.
>ISTJ - possibly unhelpful for you, I'm not sure. The ISTJ, sister type of the ESTJ, stuggles with Ne-Fe the relationship of Fe to the immediate big picture, and the micro-interconnections of the social sphere to the big picture. The ESTJ struggles less with this, and in fact, though not being much better at it than the ISTJ in certain regards, almost seems to pride themselves on it. I believe it is the nature of our weaker functional links to take on this aspirational nature and in so doing, orient our dominant functions to those domains. Like the ISTJ, ESTJs like dead-pan, punchy humor, generally.
>ENFP - They share all functions with an ENFP, in some ways it may be useful to imagine ENFP, ENFJ, ESTP, ESTJ as one group to get a sense for these extroverted types. Regardless, like an ENFP, they hold strong convictions and will, unlike an ENFP, try to fulfill the role of these convictions stoically, stolidly - as opposed to like a firecracker or a whip.
>INFP - I find ESTJs to be most similar to INFPs in how they enjoy company. Again, these two types share all the same preference of cognitive function in a different order, but the weaknesses of the INFP are the strengths of the ESTJ and vice versa. Beyond that, they are quite similar.
>ESFJ and ISFJ - these may be the most useful for you, being Fe-Ti users with Si-Ne preference, but I am an INTJ. Explaining Fe types to an INFJ would be comical. Fe-Se is my weakest link, thus all INTJs tend to have a lot to say about Ne-Fe via Te (which this entire post could amount to, no doubt).

(1/2)

I'm saying take something flat, and manipulate the two-dimensional landscape in interesting ways. Archetypality is crucial, I think.

(2/2)

>>21510235
Try not to think of it as a quiz. Think of the quizzes as merely a way for typists to allow themselves to be checked against the self-perception of the subject they are typing, and a way for individuals to get a handle on the system by self-typing. Since they are familiar with themselves, putting a type to self can be useful as an anchor for understanding the abstract concepts surrounding the functions. The system, at base, is a set of logically counter-balanced categorizations which represent an attempt to isolate and reduce an observed patient's processes to abstract concepts - for the purpose of gaining greater insight into the subject, and into all subjects at large. The quizzes are inherently flawed for several reasons, but the most noteworthy two are the following:

- every quiz author has a type. thus the quiz is influenced by the cognitive efficiencies and deficiencies of the quiz-maker(s)
- every test-taker has varied levels of self-observance and biases, as well as their own type - which will make it easier to comprehend the questions in the manner the test-taker intended, or harder, depending on the subject's relationship to the type of the quiz-writer

But for someone who understands the system, a gross mistype is easy to see. I generally try and type people before having them test, so I can refine my ability to type.

Not, OP, but I am the INTJ who posted before.

Yes. All science relies on labelling and categorization. It is a necessary, if sometimes overused process. I'm only saying this to illustrate a point: there is an entire dimension of every human subject you encounter - whether via art or in person, which is knowable, comprehensible, and examinable for which Jung and Myers-Briggs has provided the keys. >>21502754
I rarely say this buzzword meme phrase, but nice cope. Those restrictions were part and parcel of the metapolitical framing of the war. "All's fair in love and war" is a phrase for a reason. So is "war is politics by other means," and so is its inverse. This isn't 1685, we aren't fighting cabinet wars. All 20th century war is assymmetrical and self-consciously so. Vietnam played the possibilities of its situation perfectly and won at the strategic level fair and square.

It's no surprise that minor nations like Vietnam can't compete with industrial juggernauts like the Cold War era USA, one of the two remaining superpowers and geopolitical hegemons on the planet. For the USA to say "we only lost because we couldn't drop our thousands of nukes on every single rice farmer, because then international opinion would have turned on us and our tactical victory in Vietnam would have been geostrategically pyrrhic!!" is pathetic. Vietnam fought an incredible war using every single means at its disposal and proved that the pawns can outmaneuver the queens on the board of realpolitik. Vietnam's victory was so incredible that it's philosophically significant, it's a modern Thermopylae, Marathon, or Salamis. Who cares that the Persians burnt Athens? Does anyone even remember that? No, they remember Thermopylae, Marathon, and Salamis.

To say "we only lost because we couldn't disregard all metapolitical factors!! if we could have done total mobilization and destroyed our geopolitical hegemonic position and caused revolution on the home front, we could have had more tanks than you!! you had a worse K:D ratio!!!" is childish and shows a lack of understanding of war. War is the ultimate anti-cope arena, all copes go directly in the trash. Victory is victory. Vietnam won.

>>21503025
There's a couple of related purposes to the math/science part of the program. Otoh, a bunch of these readings go hand in hand with laboratory practicums (dissecting a heart reading Harvey, chemistry experiments with Lavoisier, weight and balance experiments with Archimedes and Pascal, etc), where part of the point is to learn how science developed by seeing for ourselves whether the experiments bear out the observations and conclusions of various thinkers. But in addition, since here is some broad cultural agreement on the notion of modernity being a kind of crisis, reading older workks of math and science offer an opportunity to grapple with their development and increasingly important role in culture and politics. For example, Vieta is read in sequence with some equations by Diophantus and followed up with Descartes' Geometrie to see how arithmetic comes to treat geometrical quantities and magnitudes. This is really another way of being able to see concretely what we gain and lose by formulating algebra. Similarly, we go through Ptolemy, Copernicus, Galileo, and Kepler to investigate what was involved in trying to establish the order of the solar system.

They probably develop some of the requisites for them along the way. They read some texts in ancient geometry and arithmetic (like Euclid's Elements, Nicomachus' Arithmetic), some early modern algebra and geometry works (like Vieta's Introduction to the Analytical Art and Descartes' Geometry), so even if they don't start knowing everything necessary, they should along the way be able to "catch up" by becoming acquainted with the historical predecessors for each one.
As mentioned by one of their students in this post >>21504232 , they do go through exercises and lab practices along with each one of the math and scientific texts they read, so they don't really get exactly the same experience a person who's got nothing but those original texts would get from reading them all by themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509012
>Do they even have the requisite knowledge to understand them?
Yes. Students have to pass an algebra exam sophomore year in order to be allowed to continue any further in the program. They can take as many times as they want until they pass, but if they don't pass by the end of the year, they're out; math the first two years is mostly geometry and some trig (Euclid, Ptolemy, Apollonius), culminating in Diophantine equations, Vieta, and Descartes' algebra, so the demand is that the students show they're prepared to take on the math subsequent, or at least be willing to put the effort in reviewing. Junior year starts off with Galileo for a week or two in math (covered simultaneously for a longer period in lab), and we move almost immediately into several of Leibniz's papers setting out his differential calculus via a manual with lots of notes translating the ideas for modern students. The manual also functions as a primer for the kind of calculus that we see in the rest of the Junior and Senior year math and lab authors. As far as math goes (and I was never skilled at it), Maxwell and Einstein are shockingly straightforward. Maxwell practically holds your hand from paper to paper showing how and why we start and end where we do, and Einstein just uses some of Maxwell's equations.

>>21510657
The trick to Maxwell, I think, is studying Faraday first (who we spend a about a month on before concluding Junior lab with Maxwell), since Faraday uses no math, just very astute empirical observations that are clear. In Maxwell afterwards, one finds that he's using equations to formalize those observations, and he's very focused on keeping in mind how each part of the equations correspond to certain physical phenomena. The subsequent derivations can still be tricky, and he's dry to read, but it's straightforward enough. Like reading Aristotle, Aquinas, or Kant. Getting bored following along is the difficulty.

(He's also written what look to be layman's accounts of science; I haven't taken a look at them, but they might be worth a glance.)

>This is one of those books that make me wish I could travel back in time to catch the author drafting notes. So much brilliance, so much erudition, all devoted to beating straw—at least as far as ‘Second Culture’ Enlightenment critiques are concerned. Nietzsche is the most glaring example. Ignoring Nietzsche the physiologist, the empirically-minded skeptic, and reducing him to his subsequent misappropriation by fascist, existential, and postmodernist thought, Pinker writes:

>>Disdaining the commitment to truth-seeking among scientists and Enlightenment thinkers, Nietzsche asserted that “there are no facts, only interpretations,” and that “truth is a kind of error without which a certain species of life could not live.” (Of course, this left him unable to explain why we should believe that those statements are true.) 446

>Although it’s true that Nietzsche (like Pinker) lacked any scientifically compelling theory of cognition, what he did understand was its relation to power, the fact that “when you face an adversary alone, your best weapon may be an ax, but when you face an adversary in front of a throng of bystanders, your best weapon may be an argument” (415). To argue that all knowledge is contextual isn’t to argue that all knowledge is fundamentally equal (and therefore not knowledge at all), only that it is bound to its time and place, a creature possessing its own ecology, its own conditions of failure and flourishing. The Nietzschean thought experiment is actually quite a simple one: What happens when we turn Enlightenment skepticism loose upon Enlightenment values? For Nietzsche, Enlightenment Now, though it regularly pays lip service to the ramshackle, reversal-prone nature of progress, serves to conceal the empirical fact of cognitive ecology, that we remain, for all our enlightened noise-making to the contrary, animals bent on minimizing discrepancies. The Enlightenment only survives its own skepticism, Nietzsche thought, in the transvaluation of value, which he conceived—unfortunately—in atavistic or morally regressive terms.

Who's right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21514177
it seems you've failed to comprehend the "Beyond" in Beyond Good and Evil. it's quite literally a whole book meant to poke fun at antitheticals. Nietzsche's whole approach to refutations are summed fairly quickly here in the preface to Genealogy:
>In the above-mentioned work [Dr. Ree's], on which I was then engaged, I made opportune and inopportune reference to the propositions of that book, not in order to refute them—what have I to do with refutations!—but, as becomes a positive spirit, to replace the improbable with the more probable, possibly one error with another.
of course they're not airtight. Nietzsche couldn't give less of a shit how airtight an argument is. his epistemology is historical and governed by power (where Foucault made much use of).

>Also if Neitzche advocates for overcoming slave morality so much, then why did he write this book? Is he trying to make me pray to him instead of Go?.
awful reading, but understandable. but he's much clearer in Genealogy which he uses as a preface to BNG. you'll see that he's more delineating the history that leads up to the point where we live in a mix of slave and master morality, difficult to unearth and separate from one another. bad conscience, guilt, slave morality is to him, an illness, but the same as pregnancy is an illness. note the subtitle "Prelude to a Philosophy of the Future". Nietzsche is very often always looking forward to the future, and in many ways it precludes the present being a rather botched but necessary part of it. there is no "slave bad, master good" type of thinking, though he obviously lavishes the master morality at the expense of the slave's, it is of necessity since in his timeline, the slaves have largely won, obscuring the master morality that predated it.

it's okay. you've been filtered. you just need to pick it up again after reading the parts that make some of his ideas more legible. but if you're bent on reading it badly, i think you might benefit more from just putting it down. more than anyone else, he himself knows he's not for everyone. he willingly misleads so that people who weren't meant for him never get much closer to his actual ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one. I couldn't have even been 7 years old. I distinctly remember coloring the story of the resurrection and crucifixion in the back of my grandma's old wood-paneled station wagon going to a family gathering. I had just finished coloring the white of Jesus's robe as he emerged from the tomb, the stone rolled to the side and all. I was meticulous not to color over the black lines because I wanted the robe to stand out against the cheap, greyish recycled paper of the time.

Then it hit me. It made no sense. How does a dead person come to life? Even with religion magic and what was the point? It wasn't even a true sacrifice on his or his dad's part-- he knew he was coming back to life. He HAD to or else it was pointless.

THen I remembered some of the World Books my mom had 'invested' in whereI read about Aztecs and Incas and Maya and how brutal and horrible the human sacrifice they did was and thought "Wow. Jesus wasn't THAT bad compared to how other NON-GOD people who are never coming back (and going to hell because they never heard the gospel) died."

After that moment, it was the end of it. It made no sense. I struggled for years to TRY to believe, my mom being super religious and all, but it never happened. At the ripe old age of 12 or 13 I was a full-blown atheist and around 19 or 20 I was the anti-theist I remain today (albeit with a double miajor/minor in studies around the anthropological study of world religions (was going to teach. Dodged that bullet.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21514312
Intelligence quotient (IQ) is a measure of cognitive abilities and is typically determined through standardized tests. These tests assess abilities such as reasoning, problem-solving, and verbal and mathematical skills. IQ scores are often used to indicate a person's general cognitive abilities and potential for academic and occupational success.

It's hard to estimate IQ based on a single behavior such as finding yourself having to read paragraphs multiple times in order to feel you've absorbed it. There are many factors that contribute to a person's reading comprehension and ability to absorb information. These can include things like attention span, prior knowledge, background, and reading strategies, among others.

It's worth noting that difficulty in understanding or retaining information doesn't necessarily indicate low IQ. Some people might have specific learning difficulties, such as dyslexia, that can make reading more challenging. Additionally, some people might have other strengths, such as being able to think critically or having good problem-solving skills that do not require reading multiple times.

It's important to remember that IQ is just one measure of intelligence and it doesn't take into account all the aspects of intelligence, such as emotional intelligence, creativity, and practical skills.

>>21513600
Ovid, Metamorphoses.
Homer, Iliad and Odyssey.
Hesiod, Teogony and Works and Days.
Greek Tragedies by Aeschylus, Euripides and Sophocles.
Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica.
Virgil, Aeneid.
Apollodorus, The Library (more of a reference book about Greek myths).
Eratosthenes and Hyginus, Constellation Myths.

Greek Myths by Robert Graves is a modern (20th Century) book about myths.

Lucian of Samosata (d. 180 AD) wrote several satires about Greek myths. Dialogues of the Gods is a good one, but you'll probably enjoy everything he wrote. Not too easy to find.

In short, the gods of Olympus, or of any of the other pantheons for that matter, are all essentially finite, contingent beings like us, about as impressive as extraterrestrials – which might be very impressive indeed, of course, but still within the order of creation. In particular (and to be more philosophically precise) they would all be mixtures of actuality and potentiality and compounds of essence and existence, would all be governed by principles outside themselves, and would all be less than absolutely necessary in their existence and imperfect in their natures. And that means that, no less than we do, they would depend for their being on that which is Pure Actuality, that which is Being Itself (i.e. in which essence and existence are identical), that which exists in an absolutely necessary and independent way and in which all the diverse, derivative, and finite perfections manifest in the world of our experience exist in a united, underived, and infinite way. That is to say, they, no less than we, would depend for their being on the God of classical theism.

>>21510997
I'm the Anon you originally asked. The trouble is that you are not yourself familiar with Aquinas, but only with summaries of his arguments as presented by 'people'. Who are these people you're referring to, by the way? Aquinas was not particularly concerned with natural theology, which is a part of philosophy really; the Summa is not an attempt to demonstrate the existence of God from naturally observed principles. Rather, since that truth is clearly observable, Aquians uses it as the starting point for the Summa, which is really a demonstration and summary of almost the entirety of Theology--a science which, in treating of higher things than philosophy, is a higher science than philosophy. Furthermore, as Aquinas explains, there are two senses to the word faith--the sense most are familiar with today is the notion of a strongly held opinion, but this is really the second sense. The first and more proper sense of the word is to place trust or confidence in someone or something--after all, Fide is the very root of the word con-fid-ence--with faith. Having faith in God is more properly believing God than it is believing that God exists. I know that if I drop an apple, it will fall; if I have faith in gravity, is that some speculative opinion that gravity exists? The Faith with which Aquinas treats, and of which scripture speaks is that first meaning of the word, less commonly understood today--believing God. That is, in knowing that God is all good and therefore cannot deceive nor be deceived, we must have a perfect confidence--we must have faith--in all that God communicates to man. This is faith properly so called. And because we can be sure of all that God reveals, we can be sure of all necessary conclusions drawn from revelation. The study of these conclusions and apparent conclusions is the science of Theology. The 'leap of faith' as you describe it is a novelty coined by Kierkegaard which has no place in actual Catholic theology. It is debatable whether Kierkegaard's writings are orthodox. No 'leap of faith' is necessary, and neither Thomas nor his adherents would ever suggest so. Of course, if you do not trust a man, you will not trust what he says. If you do not believe God, you will not accept what God says.

>Elaborate on this
Classical theism is really a philosophical tradition rather than theology and is not bound to any religion. Aquinas himself built on pagan(Aristotle), Jewish(Maimonides) and Islamic sources, without accepting their dogmatic theology. It aims to determine, by reason alone, that there exists necessary being(a being without which the universe simply could not exist), and that it has certain attributes(omnipotence, omnipresence, eternity, etc.). There is no faith required for this, just analysis of the arguments given. The same arguments are applicable to many different religions, as far as only the existence of such God is concerned. The identity of God of classical theism with any particular deity is different matter. Its not really possible to say with absolute certainty that God of any religion is the God of classical theism, since most religions depend on some form of divine revelation. You can, however, make a probable argument based on various religious scriptures that this or that religion better approaches what has been proved(if it has been proved) to be logically necessary. Such arguments, then, will require a certain degree of faith to assent to.

>>21511735
"Testing" means the attribution of law-like cause-effect structures, which entails a law-like, causally structured universe that is also unitary (not some lovecraftian chaos of infinitely "intersecting" but mutually absolute causal "planes" of some kind). There is a reason Newton's "discovery" of gravity led inexorably to BOTH Hume's radical scepticism about the attribution of causes to nature AND thereby to Kant's regulative ideals of science, which were an attempt to save Newtonian science.

It's a slippery slope. You want to save just enough realism (empiricism, physicalism) to make everyday secular life and scientism keep going, while denying the need for ideal entities and logical entailments at the metaphysical level. But even your "minimalist" empiricism/physicalism requires ideal entities, like the laws themselves you claim to observe "in" merely physical entities and events, and logical entailments, like the need for the causal unity of whatever universe is being described as having cause-effect relations according to laws within it.

This is an old paradox. From Hume you either get total scepticism in which case you can't do anything at all, or you have to reassert something like a rationalist metaphysical framework just to make physics deducible again. The one compromise solution was Kant's, and it made no sense and everybody immediately tried to break out of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
April 22, 1958
57 Perry Street
New York City

Dear Hume,

You ask advice: ah, what a very human and very dangerous thing to do! For to give advice to a man who asks what to do with his life implies something very close to egomania. To presume to point a man to the right and ultimate goal— to point with a trembling finger in the RIGHT direction is something only a fool would take upon himself.

I am not a fool, but I respect your sincerity in asking my advice. I ask you though, in listening to what I say, to remember that all advice can only be a product of the man who gives it. What is truth to one may be disaster to another. I do not see life through your eyes, nor you through mine. If I were to attempt to give you specific advice, it would be too much like the blind leading the blind.

“To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether ’tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles … ” (Shakespeare)

And indeed, that IS the question: whether to float with the tide, or to swim for a goal. It is a choice we must all make consciously or unconsciously at one time in our lives. So few people understand this! Think of any decision you’ve ever made which had a bearing on your future: I may be wrong, but I don’t see how it could have been anything but a choice however indirect— between the two things I’ve mentioned: the floating or the swimming.

But why not float if you have no goal? That is another question. It is unquestionably better to enjoy the floating than to swim in uncertainty. So how does a man find a goal? Not a castle in the stars, but a real and tangible thing. How can a man be sure he’s not after the “big rock candy mountain,” the enticing sugar-candy goal that has little taste and no substance? . . .

As a preliminary point, it may be noted that if everything evolved out of nothing, there would be no real, substantive argument against masturbation or homosexual practice.

But if not, if there is a divine Creator, the matter is rather different. Here is why.

In the marital act, a man and a woman become, as it were, co-workers with God in creating a new human soul, made in the image and likeness of God, which will live forever. As such, it is a sacred act.

However, our desires have been knocked all out of true by the Fall, and in particular, and in some special way, our sexual desires.

A man's erection, and the act of ejaculation have a distinct teleological purpose -- to plant the seed, and create new life.

In the case of sodomy, it is an especially perverse action -- almost a mockery of the marital act. >>21509805
My own position is that when we have sex we take part in a virtual, horizontal infinity (because generation generates beings who can themselves generate generative beings, ad infinitum).

Sex with a willful absence of openness to this infinity is an act of closure against a potentially infinite series ("I want this thing, which is intrinsically infinite, yet without infinity), and thus an infinite crime against life itself.

It is willfully withdrawing from an infinite chain of life, which is sacred, in favor of some momentary feeling.

I think the implicit premise in St. Thomas, or rather, my own intuitive response to the criticisms of his argument, is that there is something about sexuality that is distinctly important—and that "something" is simply life. New life comes from sexuality. To disconnect sexuality from life is an intrinsic crime against life.

Sure, in some sense this is nakedly ad hoc reasoning (i.e: it's not explictly present in Aquinas). Considered insensibly, I think that his argument doesn't hold.

But on the other hand, "natural law" is Aristotelian in that it reflects and formalizes what everybody already says, rather than go at things on its own. That is, it is already somewhat "ad hoc" in that it takes as one of its sources of reasoning widespread moral sentiments.

Most cultures look down on masturbation and forbid it for reasons which they may find hard to consciously articulate. I would argue that St. Thomas lived in such a chaste time that he felt that sexual sins were so obviously immoral that he did not need to bother with a very strong argument against them.

In more formal terms—the argument is not just that perverted faculties are wrong, but that when a perverted faculty pertains directly to life itself, it is wrong.

This could also retroactively support St. Thomas' argument against drunkenness, as well. Just as sex is essential to our animal nature, so is reasoning essential to our spiritual nature.

>>21510412
It's a predictor of the speed at which you adapt to novel problems and incorporate what you just learned into future solutions. This is why IQ tests aren't meant to be repeated. Everyone would have a higher score the second time, it defeats the purpose. The same for algorithms that analyze some written work. There are too many variables to derive a meaningful result.

And they are still a PREDICTOR-- an estimate, if you wish, but not even that, really. IQ has value in large scales, you can make inferences about populations relative to one another based on IQ scores and how various factors influence them. Simply taking a test and saying "I have a high IQ!" is meaningless ego-stroking. It does not measure your ability to adapt what you've learned to concrete experience, your awareness of your environment and your ability to influence it, your long-term decision making skills, or anything else we would generally consider an application of actual intelligence. It merely predicts it. It's the equivalent of getting a "yeah, you might be smart" fortune cookie. Not what you should be excited about. You still have to prove it.

>>21510472
What purpose would it serve? Do you think you're intelligent, or at least have the capacity to be so? Can you achieve things? Can you put your mind to something, especially something you've never learned or done before, and do it, at least passably? Can you compose your thoughts and present them in a way that makes someone say "Oh yeah, I get it"? What use is some arbitrary number to how you intend to live your life, other than to stroke your ego over a score that doesn't matter and doesn't tell you anything about yourself?

As I suggested, IQ has applications on a population level, but serves little to no purpose for an individual, other than the basest, most crude cases of confirmation. "Wow, that ghetto-born criminal who spent half his life in prison stealing shoes and liquor has a low IQ. Wow, that Harvard professor with a pulitzer has a high IQ. Who could have guessed?". Knowing the number before the deed means nothing, unless you want to believe the prediction you got will determine your outcome more than your actual effort.

This post seems pretty emotionally charged. There's no need to get so irritated, anon.
You seem to be going by the assumption that i somehow, somewhere, implied that IQ is everything, the sole factor, the one and only sacred number that matters above all when it comes to one's intelligence. It's not. I never considered it as such. This alone makes the entire argument in your post pointless, as it comes from a false premise and words that did not come out of my mouth.

IQ has its importance, as was said above, in what comes to societies and groups of people. It has its importance individually too, as an approximate indicator, with a certain amount of accuracy. The accuracy it has shouldn't be 100% dismissed though; we all know there are differences between the average low-IQ person and the average high-IQ person in how they reason and come to conclusions, and most well-accomplished individuals in the fields of science, philosophy and the like have very high IQ's (if not all). Of course this is not something that applies to every area in which one can be successful (art and sports, for instance, don't require it), but this doesn't mean at all that IQ should be dismissed. It's not even something up to discussion. Can you imagine, for instance, a person in any intellectual field making the exact statement that is said in the post above this? Would this person be taken seriously?

>>21510223
Estimating IQ by a computer program analyzing a passage of writing is incredibly flawed. Yes, you can more or less ascertain the difference between an illiterate hobo and a Nobel Prize winner by sticking pieces of their writing into the program, but the conception that it’ll give you an accurate number is risible. By definition, firstly, it could only be testing for verbal IQ, and not other aspects of IQ like mathematical abilities, reasoning abilities, memory, processing speed, and visual-spatial processing. Furthermore, if someone like Hemingway or Raymond Carver is deliberately writing in a bare-bones simplified way (with simplistic syntax and a pared-down vocabulary), whereas another writer like Joyce or Gass, or even a philosopher like Heidegger, is painstakingly and laboriously crafting very verbose and abstruse sentences, this will also sway their IQ score either lower or higher, when really it’s a highly artificial product of their intelligence which could either be obscuring or inflating their actual intelligence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21507941
There’s a passage where the kid asks what Judge Holden is “a judge of” and (the expriest, I believe) doesn’t give any answer. McCarthy intentionally describes the judge’s background very opaquely, imo. I think he did this in order to foster some interpretations that the judge may not actually be a tangible figure, but rather an inner concept of the kid or of the gang members. I’m sure there are also other similar abstracted interpretations that one could derive from his character in the book. Just my thoughts, though. Of course, Blood Meridian is actually inspired from an autobiography, Samuel Chamberlain’s My Confessions. In which, Judge Holden is described as a real person who participated in the Glanton Gang in the 1800s. It’s unclear whether this alleged member was actually a judge, and some also “Judge Holden” to be a nickname of one of the gang members rather than any real title or name.

posts.name: Anonymouṡ
posts.com:
>>21514371
They're both grammatically correct, but they have slightly different meanings.

>He mentioned that the professor was American
This emphasizes that he mentioned a fact about the professor's nationality which was true when he mentioned it. It makes no promises about the professor's nationality NOW.

>He mentioned that the professor is American
This says that the professor was and is American, and he mentioned this fact.

We can highlight this difference by picking something more mutable than the professor being American.

— He mentioned that it was almost 6 o'clock, so we ordered two large pizzas.

That's fine. You wouldn't say:

— He mentioned that it is almost 6 o'clock, so we ordered two large pizzas.

I'd love to entertain this thought. I mean, what academic in the last 40 years hasn't stroked their 4 inchers to Keats? And what writers 50 years before that hasn't dabbled with a tug on their 5ers? I mean, for Christ's sake, Fitzgerald had a copy of nightingale stitched to his ribcage and more than once just snagged a phrase or two from it.

That all said, there just isn't enough of Keats to warrant such a place. He once said, and I'm paraphrasing and really hoping to get back to this Peterson Flake I'm smoking, so bear with me, "I know I'll be considered amongst the English poets." Is he? Sure, he's considered. But a handful of odes (great may they be), the better parts of Hyperion, and whatever you can take from Endymion does not a number one poet make. I remember in my youth being dumbfounded that everyone praised him so highly, as most of it went over my head and didn't make a lick of sense. It wasn't until I delved into the period that the brambles of Keats' dark and deeply metaphysical mind unraveled in their paradoxical way and led to beauty. Reading him alongside contemporaries, not just Shelley and Byron, but John Clare and Felicia Hemens leads to the most graspable and lovable quality of Keats. Not to say those last two are lame poets, Clare especially is interesting to me for some reason (maybe the mental hospitals), but Johnny Keats just bent around himself and his fundamental Grecian predilections in a (and I mean this next word as fully as I can) poetic way.

So yes, he's great. The bloom, whose petals nipped before they blew, who died on the promise of fruit and all that. Maybe he was even the best of the period, though again, Shelley and Byron (Wordsworth, too, at least his early stuff (love ought to be paid to the origin of things (and let's not forget Coleridge, Blake, and, God forbid, the women.) are all worth a look.

I'm rambling, and with all these parenthetical I'm afraid one of you might confuse me for Salinger (or a bored Pynchon), and I do have more to say about another names in the thread (ask me about Joyce. James Joyce) but that pesky peterson in that briar wood is making eyes at me again and has stopped smoking, so off I'll go.

Capote: Well, it has brought about the rise of what I call the Jewish Mafia in American letters. This is a clique of New York-oriented writers and critics who control much of the literary scene through the influence of the quarterlies and intellectual magazines. All these publications are Jewish-dominated and this particular coterie employs them to make or break writers by advancing or withholding attention. I don’t think there’s any conscious, sinister conspiracy on their part—just a determination to see that members of their particular clique rise to the top. Bernard Malamud and Saul Bellow and Philip Roth and Isaac Bashevis Singer and Norman Mailer are all fine writers, but they’re not the only writers in the country, as the Jewish literary Mafia would have us believe. I could give you a list of excellent writers, such as John Knowles and Vance Bourjaily and James Purdy and Donald Windham and Reynolds Price and James Leo Herlihy and Calder Willingham and John Hawkes and William Goyen; the odds are you haven’t heard of most of them, for the simple reason that the Jewish Mafia has systematically frozen them out of the literary scene. Now, mind you, I’m not against any particular group adhering to its own literary values and advancing its own favored authors; such cliques have always existed in American letters. I only object when any one particular group—and it could just as well be Southern, or Roman Catholic, or Marxist, or vegetarian—gets a strangle hold on American criticism and squeezes out anybody who doesn’t conform to its own standards. It’s fine to write about specifically Jewish problems, and it often makes valid and exciting literature—but the people who have other messages to convey, other styles and other backgrounds should also be given a chance. Today, because of the predominance of the Jewish Mafia, they’re not being given that opportunity. This is something everyone in the literary world knows but never writers about.

>>21509145
If you subscribe to Aristotle then even tragedies are life-affirming in a way as tried and tested through the centuries they still are a direct link to the nerve centre of human experience. But other than tragedies, the last book Time Regained in Proust’s In Search of Lost Time and Joyce’s Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man and Ulysses are some of the most unambiguously life-affirming books I’ve read. It’s also on the OP chart but The Book of Ebenezer Le Page is wonderful and truly underrated. It does conform more with Aristotle’s model though since it’s certainly not bereft of tragedy, but of course that’s precisely what makes it life-affirming. Really the Greeks had it all figured out.

My favorite obscure hipster form of white-on-white racism during the 19th century would be anti-Mormon orientalistic scientific racism in the United States. Basically, non-Mormon WASPy America started to use scientific racism to argue that Mormons, though predominantly of British and Scandinavian descent at the time, were literally evolving into a new, but lower race. They associated their religious beliefs/practices (living Abrahamic prophets and polygamy) and their living in a literal desert (Utah wilderness) with the emergence of a new race. They also felt that part of the evolution was a result of Mormons intermarrying with non-whites through their proselytizing efforts worldwide, as well as with the native Americans they preached to, and that the lower clases from Europe were the ones usually drawn to Mormonism. So they were able to explain the mutations partly from these supposed unique racial origins concentrating in one isolated place, and they took the religious practices as evidence of psychological degeneracy, while they saw the desert location as a conditioning agent helping the mutation. The best part of anti-Mormon orientalist scientific racism is that people started to say that Mormons were actually physically starting to look post-white. Here's my favorite description of supposed Mormon post-whiteness:
>an expression of countenance and a style of feature, which may be styled the Mormon expression and style; an expression compounded of sensuality, cunning, suspicion, and smirking self-conceit. The yellow, sunken, cadaverous visage; the greenish-colored eyes; the thick, protuberant lips; the low forehead; the light, yellowish hair; and the lank, angular person, constitute an appearance so characteristic of the new race, the production of polygamy, as to distinguish them at a glance.

There were four main migrations to america from britain
The first were puritans, middle class well offs from urban east anglia who were too religious and crazy for England and went to the americas. they settled new england
the second were the cavaliers, upper class landowners and their servants and rural workers who came from the rural south of england. they settled in virginia and the deep south
the third were quakers from the west midlands and wales, who like the puritans immigrated because of their religion but were pacifists and hated hierarchies and believed in egalitarianism. they settled in pennsylvania
the third were the borderers, rural poor from the north of england and the lowlands of scotland, many of whom had been planted in northern ireland (hence the term "scots irish", although it makes no sense if you read up about them). They settled in appalachia

>By the eighteenth century, the culture of this region bore littleresemblence to the customs of the ancient Celts. The dominant language
was English—unlike that of Gaelic-speaking Irish Catholic peasants,Scottish highlanders, Welsh cottagers, and Cornish miners. The borderers had comparatively little contact (much of it hostile) with these Celticpeople. In the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, it was observed that“the Ulster settlers mingled freely with the English Puritans and Huguenots,” but married very rarely with the Gaelic-speaking people of Ireland and Scotland.
>"Few Gaelic-speaking people emigrated from Ireland, Cornwall or Walesto the American colonies before the nineteenth century. Celtic Irish immigrants were excluded by law from some American colonies. A South Carolina statute of 1716 forbade “what is commonly called native Irish, or persons of known scandalous character or Roman Catholics.”22Gaelic-speaking Scottish highlanders also were ethnically distinct fromthe borderers. There was no love lost between lowland and highland Scots,who differed in language, politics, religion and culture. In America, Scottishhighlanders tended to settle apart in North Carolina’s Cape Fear Valley,where Gaelic continued to be spoken even into the late twentieth century.Many of these transplanted highlanders became Tories in the American Revolution, largely because their border neighbors were Whig. The fighting between them was as savage as any conflict in North Britain.23"
Albions Seed is the greatest historical work on British migrations to america.

>identify any topic or subject of interest that you like
>research its history
>discover that its modern iteration was in all likelihood built on the work of Anglos
For example my interest is in Platonism and what you discover when you look at translations and scholarship on Platonism and Platonic revival is that (autistic) Anglos were the powerhouses behind it.
Another thing worth mentioning is that England has a very rich history but each period is very different from the rest. For example, Anglo-Saxon England is cool but not especially interesting IMO. Medieval England is captivating because of its complexity and activity - the wars in France and the crusades are super cool. If you like knights, you should read up on the reign of Richard the Lionheart for sure. He's like the quintessential knightly prince. After the medieval period, personally I find English history really boring up until the modern period when suddenly shit hits the fan every which way. Victorian era to 1930 is peak history kino.
IMO one of the best things about England is reading about the cultural, philosophical etc work that was being done. English philosophy is shit but on the margins of the discipline the English did lots of really awesome shit, like translating rare ancient texts and such.

>>21509764
It's very difficult to explain why I like this book as much as I do and it's one of those books that can sometimes struggle on the translations; if you can read Spanish, grab a Spanish copy over an English copy or whatever your mother tongue is.
Personally, I enjoy it a lot. The book isn't so much about self-improvement as it is about delusions of grandeur, mental health and the effects of one person in a bad way affects those around him in a negative fashion.
Obviously, the book is first and foremost about a 40 something year old man that dresses up as a knight, acts like a knight and believes he's a knight to save a woman who may not exist and if that's how you take the book, that's fine.
The themes aren't all surface level, so you can get a lot out of disecting the book in its 2 parts; the first part is more comedy focused whilst the second part is surprisingly dark.
Someone already said that part 1 slaps part 2, but for me, I prefer it the other way around; in part 2, we see not only what part 1 has done to Don Quixote but more importantly, what it does to Sancho Panza, his companion and the most level-headed character in the whole cast. I don't want to spoil the book too much, but I enjoy that during one bit of Part 2 a certain "thing" happens and Sancho tries to do a bad "thing" so that he can get out of all of this.
The book doesn't have a happy ending, but most books in this time period don't if we're being honest. I'd be happy to go into it in more depth, but I'm trying to restrain myself from spoiling this too much which you may consider arbitrary because the book is hundereds of years old.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509904
The main ones are class identity, sanity and madness (in the elderly), idealism vs realism but the big one is understanding the truth and defending lies.
Some of the big parts of the Truth vs Lies is that "Seeing is believing" and there are numerous times where what Don and Sancho see are completely different with arguably the most famous being the tilting at windmills scene.
It all boils down to "Private VS Communal truth" if you will and Don's need to understand why a truth that is private can be self-destructive and his character grows to understand why a communal truth is more acceptable, but it's a little more complicated than that.
The Madness vs Sanity angle is closely connected, especially considering that Don doesn't have constant illusions around him, but only when his imagination is captivated by the books he read before he departs.
The class identity ties into self-invention a lot; the very first scene, Don essentially invents himself and it's this invention of who he is that drives everything within the story; it's akin to a child playing pretend, but in a world where there is only one player and everyone else is merely a spectator with some wishing to help/deal with Don in their own way, or play along by appeasing his imagination of himself and the world around him. As a knight, Don's "class" moreso within himself, is of a chivalrous, powerful, important man and carries himself with this haughty attitude everywhere he goes, throwing his weight around and acting superior, yet benevolent. He wants to project his powerful image to fight back a cynical, vile, vituperative world devoid of imagination and heart; he wants a piece of himself within all of those he sees around him.
The Idealism vs Realism angle is mainly explored in the two leads, the idealist Don and the realist Sancho. Sancho is the "Straight man" to Don's "Absolute fucking moron". Don isn't stupid though, but his idealist tendencies tend to struggle to fit in the world around him; where Don sees beliefs, Sancho sees Detail, Don is tall and thin, Sancho is short and squat; they're deliberate opposites in this world and their grasps on the world they live in are shown with heart and understanding, without undermining either view because after all, the world has a reason and indeed a need for idealists, but realists are just as important. Without idealism, realists become too grounded and without realism, idealists struggle to cope and understand with that which is around them.
I hope this helps, at least a bit and if anyone else wants to chime in, that'd be cool.

>>21510173
That's one of the big bits of the whole idealism vs realism angles.
Most, if not all people know that Don dies at the end, and denounces chivalry and idealism as a whole, but it wasn't these things that hurt him as much as it was his failure to accept realism in any capacity until he fully switched sides right before his death.
After everything, life is to be challenged and not skirted around by flights of fancy; lifes many challenges need to be tackled directly but the tragedy of the book is that what Don ultimately wanted, was to do good, to be a good person, to do good things, to teach others to do good. Realism's victory over Don is that it robs a man of his fantasy, his desire and imagination, his idealism; no man can be an idealist or realist in full because if they are, they simply aren't living a life worth living in and once Don realises that his idealism is harmful and reaches his ultimate truth that it was the only guiding light he chose to follow, we see a broken man.
Don's flaw was that he was narrow-minded and followed his creed and law to the letter, in a constant, to the detriment of himself and his others; we all know the famous line "The road to hell is paved with good intentions" and it's a massive part of the novel as a whole.
Idealism can lead to ignorance, arrogance and naïvety.
Realism can lead to apathy, nihilism and anhedonia.
Both of these killed Don on their own, because he only took one or the other and never in his entire time in the book did he take both.

But I imagine that all the good bachelor’s efforts will not suffice to restore sanity to a man so hopelessly mad; and if it were not contrary to charity, I would say that Don Quixote should never be cured, because when he regains his health we lose not only his amusing words and actions, but those of his squire, Sancho Panza, any one of which could cheer melancholy itself.

>>21513537
AI's ability to synthesize existing art to create something new is different from how humans create art in a few key ways. For one, AI is not constrained by the same physical limitations as humans, and can process and analyze large amounts of data in a very short amount of time. Additionally, AI can be programmed to follow specific rules and algorithms when creating art, which can result in a highly stylized and unique output.

Humans on the other hand, are influenced by their own experiences, emotions, and personal perspectives when creating art. They tend to be less predictable and more varied in their artistic expression.

It's also important to note that AI-generated art is not completely without human input. It still requires human programmers to create the algorithm and decide the parameters for the AI to work with. Therefore, the AI-generated art is a combination of human input and machine output.

It's also worth mentioning that the argument of nature vs nurture is a complex and ongoing debate in psychology and neuroscience. Some argue that both nature and nurture play a role in human development and behavior, and that the relationship between them is not always clear cut. Therefore, it is hard to make a definite statement on how much of human artistic expression is influenced by nature or nurture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21513553
It is possible that AI may eventually surpass human achievements in the field of literature, as AI has the ability to process and analyze large amounts of data quickly and can be programmed to follow specific rules and algorithms when creating text. However, it's important to note that AI-generated literature is not entirely without human input. AI-generated literature typically requires human programmers to create the algorithm and decide the parameters for the AI to work with, so ultimately the final product is a combination of human input and machine output.

Additionally, while AI may be able to produce text that is technically proficient, it may lack the emotional depth and nuance that is often present in literature written by humans. Also, literature is a form of art and not just data analysis and language generation, it reflects the complexity of human emotions, imagination, and experiences which AI may not be able to fully replicate.

In conclusion, AI has the potential to generate literature that is technically proficient, but whether it can surpass human achievements in the field of literature remains to be seen, and will depend on how well AI can replicate the emotional depth and nuance that is often present in literature written by humans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21508401
No, because both demand full devotion.
HOWEVER, Paul Valery knew science rather well and corresponded with Einstein, was friends with de Broglie, Borel, understood higher mathematics, read Poincaré, etc. Cormac McCarthy nowadays is similar.
Also, Borodin was a very good composer and important chemist. He's probably the only post-1800's person to be *actually known* for contributions both in an art and in a science. But he was not great in either - merely good/very good.

Back in the day, science was easier, way less specialized, so you could have people like Omar Khayyam and some Ancient Greeks who could be important mathematicians/scientists and also major poets at the same time.

It's easier to find "polymathy" when the areas are related. For instance, Jean Cocteau was a major writer, but also a major filmmaker and a fine draughtsman and decent actor. Nietzsche was a major writer, philosopher and an important philologist. Wagner was a major composer, essayist and playwright.

I also believe that the sciences, outside of biology and others for which careful observation is key, demand somewhat different abilities than those demanded by literature. I believe this because of people like Paul Dirac, who was such a scientific master, yet completely blind to poetry and many other things. Apparently, he even had a hard time learning French as a young boy, though his dad made a conscious effort to teach it to him. Literary kids, on the other hand, will usually learn foreign languages by themselves, with sheer joy, and even invent new ones.
With that being said, there is a lot that is similar between literature and, say, mathematics. But maths is an art in the same way making baskets is; literature is different, for it contains no well-defined goals and standard procedures.

He's right though - if Soviets were the entire root, then Poland and Germany could easily establish and anti-Soviet alliance.

But Nazi leadership was straight up more interested in annexation of polish territories than with containing Soviets, and at the same time Poland was not interested in alliances with either Germans or Soviets, as they hoped to play a neutral buffer between the two harvesting all the benefits of trade and transit between the two without actually having to commit to a side and risk war, all while being supported economically and politically by Britain and France (which also had no political forces interested in a Poland allied to either Germany or USSR).

The conflict here is not that Germany wanted to save everyone from the Commies but nobody listened - a position as laughable as that of believing that Soviets just wanted to save everyone from Nazis but nobody listened. Instead it's that Poland, Britain and France wanted an independent Poland with Germany and USSR locked in a perpetual indecisive cold confrontation, while USSR and Germany both did not want an independent Poland, and were gearing up for a hot conflict.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21510972
>How do people listen to audio books?

This depends on a lot of things. Audiobooks are a god tier gift, if you found the books/genre you like.

The basic rule of "how to" listen to audiobooks is generally
>are you bored? If yes, listen to an audiobook right where you are.

Of course there are other places, like driving a car, where you are not really bored, but still have free space in your head to listen to an audiobook, especially on the highway. You could even argue that audiobooks make you more aware of your surrounding, because your whole brain gets stimulated and if something on the road changes, your brain can instantly use all of its capacity to react.

Personally, I listen to audiobooks on three occasions
>when driving a car
When I drive, I listen to self help audiobooks. Those audiobooks are great because I re"read" them anyway and even if I forget some things, I will always profit from listening to them, even while driving.
>when doing time consuming, but completely easy and safe, stuff
For example when I cook, clean the room, wash my dick, be an evil sullying coward of the Machiavellian kind, do laundry, or do anything else that is basically just existing, I always have an audiobook nearby. You have no idea how god like audiobooks are. I literally cleaned my whole home without even noticing it while listening to audiobooks. The same with cleaning dishes or cooking. If you hate doing the needful at home, try listening to an audiobook while doing it.
>to sleep
I always had problems to sleep. There were simply so many things going on, that my brain was always occupied with something. Thanks to audiobooks I now sleep whenever I want without problems. I just use the timer in audible to set it to one hour and listen with my whole attention to the fantasy book. If I still can't sleep after one hour, I simply repeat this process until I sleep. The best part is that if it takes me hours to sleep, I now have read hours of books. And guess what? Since this win/win situation of either reading or sleeping, I barely even scratch the 30 minutes mark before I'm asleep.

I exclusively use audible and I buy my audiobooks through audible (I only buy really long audiobooks, so I don't really care. Especially because I love to relistening). I know Youtube has insane amounts of free audiobooks, but the audible app is good enough for me. Especially the possiblity to have audible always with me, on my PC, on my phone, and literally on every device with internet connection, and being able to already continue listening where I left is something I simply can't get from downloading free audiobooks and then managing everything on my own.

Three Zen Sutras: The Heart Sutra, the Diamond Sutra, and the Platform Sutra translated by Red Pine is a good introduction.

I also think the Blue Cliff Record translated by Thomas Cleary is good too, but it's a more advanced text.

Also, if you get serious about it, you can pick a specific school to practice and read specific texts from that. I went with Soto, so I read texts by Shohaku Okamura. Soto is very different from early Ch'an with its heavy emphasis on sitting meditation, and it's not for everyone.

Reading some Ch'an poetry can be nice too. I like Han Shan and Stonehouse.

As long as you understand the difference between pity and empathy, and power and will-to-power you should be fine. And don't take everything he says in more allegorical works seriously. Remember to compare it to the rest of his work for context. Whenever reading Nietzsche's takes on women, nations, politics, or any other contemporary issue, remember the culture and time period in which he made these observations, and try to properly adapt them to our own time rather than blindly accepting them. For example most of Nietzsche's writings about the differences between men and women aren't really relevant anymore, due to changing social values and the acceptance of women performing traditionally masculine tasks. Although Nietzsche did predict that the sexes may become psychologically identical in the next few centuries in passage 425 of Human, All too Human.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: After I lost my job because of coof hysteria I came to the realization that I've been wasting my life. I decided not to settle for mediocrity or misery. I started writing seriously. I've always loved doing it and tried writing a book in college, but I gave up because I was inexperienced, immature, and distracted at the time. This time, I mean it. After two years of writing whenever I had the time to do so, I just finished my first draft a couple weeks ago. I'm editing now, finding a cover artist, and will self publish because there's absolutely no chance a publishing house will want this story. I don't care if it doesn't make even a penny. I want the feel of triumph in being able to hold it in my hands and read my own novel exactly how I envisioned it. And you know what? If just one person picks it up and enjoys it, well, that will mean the world to me.

>>21509375

I have worked with editors who have never even seen my face in person

I did a lot of ghostwriting early on as well, so a lot of my work has someone else's name on it

Writing is an art and you can live however you want if you can make a living from your words as an artist/craftsman

Used to sling words for $0.01 each it was rough, but Dickens used to scrape by cranking out serials and news reports

Journalism is not a bad place to start for writers, a lot of novelists cut their teeth with journalism

You need to think deeply about the practical facts of making a living as a writer, that will motivate you to produce work that you can make a living from

>>21509350
>I don't care if it doesn't make even a penny.
>I want the feel of triumph in being able to hold it in my hands and read my own novel exactly how I envisioned it.
Those are the most important points in anything you do in life.

If you want to break your shackles, you need to finally say "FUCK EVERYTHING" and just "DO IT" until you either die trying, or finish your goal.

The most important thing so many people don't understand about improving in something is that 99 % of the time they will find a new path and end up with something completely different that fulfills them.

Also look what happens to most writers like GRRM or Rothfuss. They can't finish a new book because of the pressure of "success". Even Sanderson, who is famous for actually finishing his books, is struggling with new books because of this pressure of "succeeding".

The is nothing more amazing than being the "underdog" who has no skin in the game. Right now you don't have 100 people depend on the success of your book. Right now you can just write without having a publisher or helper telling you stuff like "don't make this character look like this" or "add this to your book", so we can sell this merch.

The good thing about writing fantasy books without a publisher is that you are free to do whatever you want. The moment you make millions and have employees, your writing is now a commercial enterprise and not for your own fun anymore.

Everything has a good and a bad side. The problem is that retards only think about "MUH COLOR OF BUGATTI!" and don't understand that money is worthless for happiness. Sure, having more money is better than having less money, but every successful person says the same thing if you ask him what the happiest time in his life was
>I remember when I was poor and struggling. No matter how much money I have now, I'm the happiest when I think about the time when everything started. When I was just me and fought to improve.

When you write books, you will always remember your journey. This is more worth than all gold on earth. Or as Alexander the Great would have said shortly before his death "When I'm dead, I can't take anything with me. The only thing the world will remember from me is what I left other people to remember and not what the color of my bugatti was"

posts.com:
After going through a medium-scale life breakdown, I got a sort of obsessive urge to create something of my own, something that ONLY I could create and nobody else, no matter what it took. After about 7 years of note taking with hundreds upon hundreds of pages of random crap, and workshopping different mediums, I finally decided that my story would be best expressed as a novel. I finally got around to actually starting it about 1 year ago, and progress is painfully slow, as I’m only about 130 pages in (decently polished though) of what I think will turn out to be about 1300 pages, and I’m struggling even harder to think of ways to “sell” it to a publisher. The more I write though, the faster it gets, so it might only take me 3-4 years instead of 10.
Like other anons ITT said, I honestly just hope that I can find and connect with a very small handful of readers that will appreciate my work. I’m not a transblack queerfaggot, and I don’t have the marketability of Harry Potter houses or something like that, so I don’t anticipate a big push into commercial success. But such is the nature of the creative business. It’s all more for me than for other people, and that’s okay. Success would be nice, but it brings its own baggage along for the ride that you may not have signed up for.

All three books have deeper socio-political themes, but my primary goal is surface level entertainment.
>Panther Pride is a story of middle schoolers who riot due to broken air conditioning and an ill-timed pep rally. They manage to seize control of the building, but then rapidly split into two different groups, each with different aims. The nerdier kids want to use the riot as an opportunity to negotiate with the school for reforms, whereas the more athletic kids just want to wreck things and have fun. The attempts of the adults to regain control of the school are baffled by a mysterious Cuban student's uncanny knack for asymmetrical warfare, as well as protestors outside the school who use the riots as an excuse to air their own personal grievances with society.
I assure you, it's not a direct rip-off of Lord of the Flies.
>The Savage Green is about a paramilitary contractor who has been hired to recover a renegade scientist from the wilderness of the Florida panhandle. He soon finds himself embroiled in a fever dream hellscape populated with vicious wildlife, inbred Confederate holdouts, and a powerful supernatural force which threatens to unleash Florida on the entire world. On the flipside, a man born and raised in Florida must come to terms with his own arrogance in the face of God, and hopefully redeem himself through an act of genuine faith.

>Modem Waves is about a veteran of a capitalist militia who now lives in a socialist breakaway state in the Pacific Northwest. After he is hijacked by the younger sister of his dead squadmate, he finds himself forced to participate in a desperate scheme to restore a version of the United States which never actually existed.
This was meant to be an inversion of the YA dystopian genre, in the sense that young adults are now running a dystopia. It's been compared to the Fallout games, but I've never played them.

I hate this website and hate captcha

So I'm gonna attempt to post this a few times and hopefully it works

For old times sake. Sorry for reddit spacing. Grad student of phil. Force of habit to punctuate.

But fulcanelli is legit. His writings at least. Persona may be imaginary.

Evola is alright. Jung is alright too. More similar than you'd think.

If you want some dope modern scholarship which is free online then look for aaron cheak's circumambulating the alchemical tradition article which iirc is available on the rubedo press website -- it is the first chapter of one of the best recent english books on the subject

If you want to read about alchemy historically then pick up the alchemy reader perhaps. Then delve into hermetica. Copenhaver has best notes. Scott has translation and original. Mead has a mason theosophy inspired history and translation called thrice greatest hermes. There's some cheaper ones without notes but I'd recommend the more scholarly ones unless you are already versed on myth magic gnosticism neoplatonism and paganism and so on in western antiquity.

Best secondary work on Hermes is Egyptian Hermes. Tour de force. Vindicates claims of prechristian egyptian origin

Best secondary work on esotericism generally is Western Esotericism: A Guide for the Perplexed by Wouter Hanegraaf then maybe download the dictionary on gnosis and esotericism of his and read entries on magic and occult and esoteric and neoplatonism and gnosticism and hermeticism and platonism and paganism and neopaganism and mysticism and masonry and rosicrucianism and renaissance and art of memory and noesis and gnosis and such

Very academic but summarizes current state of field

PS: If you like Guenon/Evola/Jung/Crowley check out Eliade and Culianu! Shamanism is a classic by former in addition to him creating religious studies generally and has curious pseudo-nietzscheanism and everything translated from latter is pure fire, straight bangers, etc. -- I also think all esotericists should consider reading Strauss wrt esotericism in philosophy proper. I do not completely agree but am sympathetic.

PPS: Once you've read all this, check out Occult Mind: Magic in Theory and Practice if you wanna continue the academic side of things... allusive and elusive but possibly my favorite book I read the year before last...

>Alchemy changes the character of things, and raises them up into higher states of existence. To exercise this power, not mere mechanical labour, but artistic skill is required.

>“To grasp the invisible elements; to attract them by their material correspondences; to control, purify, and transform them by the living power of the Spirit—this is true alchemy.

>As the fowl produces a chicken with wings and legs out of the small microcosm contained in the shell of an egg, so the arcana of Nature are ripened by the processes of alchemy. Natural alchemy causes the pear to ripen, and produces grapes on a vine. Natural alchemy separates the useful elements from the food that is put into the stomach, transforms it into chyle and blood, into muscles and bones, and rejects that which is useless. A physician who knows nothing of alchemy can only be a servant of Nature, however well he may be versed in the science of external things; but the alchemist is her lord. If the physician cannot infuse vitality into decaying parts, he cannot effect a cure, but must wait until Nature accomplishes the task; but he who can guide the power of life can guide and command Nature.”

posts.com:
What is alchemy? Half a century ago there was little doubt in the West. It was a superstition among ignorant ancients that, by certain manipulations, base metals could be turned into gold.

Then, when Freudian and Jungian ideas began to circulate in Europe, a new, enlightened view of alchemy became fashionable. The alchemists were psychoanalysing themselves. They were sublimating and calcining their own subconscious. Their real aim was not to make gold but to make a non-aberrated man.

As pursuits of this kind in the Middle Ages overlapped territory which the Church held to be its own, the alchemists had been obliged to conceal what they were really doing behind an apparently lunatic attempt to turn lead into gold.

Even for the new psychological avant-garde this explanation was not entirely satisfactory, because it was well known that even in the 20th century highly intelligent men in Fez, Cracow, Damascus, Paris and London were currently engaged in attempts to make perfectly tangible yellow gold. They had given up charcoal furnaces and were using Calor gas, but they were manifestly doing something with pots and pans, and not with Egos and Ids.

Perhaps all external ideas about the nature of alchemy could be put into four views, separately or in combination:

First View: It is possible to transmute one element into another. One such transmutation is lead or iron into gold. From some unimaginable antiquity, a mighty secret has been handed down which shows how to do this. It is the most closely kept secret in human history.

Second View: Alchemy is the science of purifying man’s inner nature and arriving at a non-aberrated individual. Such an individual would have, by comparison with ordinary men, certain advanced powers. For political reasons, this exercise had to be concealed in a pseudo-science of metal refining to which the Church would have no reason to object.

Third View: Metals CAN be transmuted. Lead CAN be turned into gold. An alchemist knows how to do this, and also knows a greater secret. If he is in a certain relation to the crucible in which the process happens, a comparable transmutation takes place in his own common presence. As lead turns into gold in the crucible, the operator’s mind is transformed. He is subjected to something like nuclear radiation. Also, certain chemical by-products in the crucible are capable of being stored and used to either make more gold or to transform other men. Hence legends of “The Sly Man’s Pill” and the Elixir which Saint-Germain is supposed to have offered Casanova when he was dying.

Fourth View: An alchemist is a man who knows an immensely powerful method of cleaning the Augean stable of his own subconscious mind. Pushed far enough, this process gives rise to a true soul-body inholding the properties of a different order of things. If this soul-body is directed on the base metals in a certain way (projection), it will accomplish a comparable transmutation in inorganic matter.

>Since all things are God, in all things thou seest just so much of God as thy capacity affordeth thee.
Aleister Crowley, The Vision and the Voice: With Commentary and Other Papers (Equinox IV:2)

But it so happens that everything on this planet is, ultimately, irrational; there is not, and cannot be, any reason for the causal connexion of things, if only because our use of the word "reason" already implies the idea of causal connexion. But, even if we avoid this fundamental difficulty, Hume said that causal connexion was not merely unprovable, but unthinkable; and, in shallower waters still, one cannot assign a true reason why water should flow down hill, or sugar taste sweet in the mouth. Attempts to explain these simple matters always progress into a learned lucidity, and on further analysis retire to a remote stronghold where every thing is irrational and unthinkable.

If you cut off a man's head, he dies. Why? Because it kills him. That is really the whole answer. Learned excursions into anatomy and physiology only beg the question; it does not explain why the heart is necessary to life to say that it is a vital organ. Yet that is exactly what is done, the trick that is played on every inquiring mind. Why cannot I see in the dark? Because light is necessary to sight. No confusion of that issue by talk of rods and cones, and optical centres, and foci, and lenses, and vibrations is very different to Edwin Arthwait's treatment of the long-suffering English language.

Knowledge is really confined to experience. The laws of Nature are, as Kant said, the laws of our minds, and, as Huxley said, the generalization of observed facts.

It is, therefore, no argument against ceremonial magic to say that it is "absurd" to try to raise a thunderstorm by beating a drum; it is not even fair to say that you have tried the experiment, found it would not work, and so perceived it to be "impossible." You might as well claim that, as you had taken paint and canvas, and not produced a Rembrandt, it was evident that the pictures attributed to his painting were really produced in quite a different way.

You do not see why the skull of a parricide should help you to raise a dead man, as you do not see why the mercury in a thermometer should rise and fall, though you elaborately pretend that you do; and you could not raise a dead man by the aid of the skull of a parricide, just as you could not play the violin like Kreisler; though in the latter case you might modestly add that you thought you could learn.

This is not the special pleading of a professed magician; it boils down to the advice not to judge subjects of which you are perfectly ignorant, and is to be found, stated in clearer and lovelier language, in the Essays of Thomas Henry Huxley.

>Aleister Crowley

Pasqually's system was some kind of proto-Scottish Rite thing where the candidate denounces normal masonry in favour of """real""" masonry, while Saint-Martin I think initially didn't tie it to a masonic structure but was nonetheless heavily involved in masonry

Since 1983 it's been less clear what actually happens but at the very least its a grave sin (read: no sacraments) and possibly the excommunication might still be in effect
